Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), anemia (low red blood cell count), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) due to bone marrow suppression.
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, Bilirubi: Elevated liver enzymes or bilirubin levels, indicating possible hepatotoxicity.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated levels in cases of kidney involvement or dysfunction.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects, though this varies with the underlying condition.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Reduced levels due to suppression of inflammatory responses.
Serum Amylase and Lipase: Elevated levels indicating potential drug-induced pancreatitis.
Serum Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM): Reduced levels due to suppression of B-cell function.
Trough Drug Levels: Abnormal therapeutic drug levels if monitored in specific cases for toxicity or efficacy.
Peripheral Blood Smear: Cytopenias (reduced blood cells) and changes in cell morphology due to bone marrow suppression.
Urinalysis: Proteinuria or hematuria in cases of renal involvement.
Serum Electrolytes (Potassium, Magnesium: Abnormal levels depending on associated renal dysfunction or electrolyte disturbances.
Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT/Coombs Tes: Positive in cases of drug-induced hemolytic anemia.
Serum LDH: Elevated levels in cases of hemolysis or cellular damage.
CMV PCR (Cytomegalovirus Polymerase Chai: Elevated viral load due to increased susceptibility to viral infections from immunosuppression.
EBV PCR (Epstein-Barr Virus Polymerase C: Elevated viral load, potentially increasing the risk of post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD).
Bone Marrow Biopsy: May show hypocellularity or suppressed bone marrow activity in cases of severe cytopenias.
